awd_titl_txt: Conference: Election Science, Research, and Administration
awd_abstract_narration:
Election scientists utilize social science theory to understand how elections operate and how citizens perceive them. The central goal of this conference is to build basic research capacity in election science, an interdisciplinary field of scholarship that focuses on the study of election administration and election conduct. The conference will bring together election scholars, election practitioners, and local election-level experts to discuss and disseminate electoral science research. The inclusion of election administrators allows interaction between science, policy, and policymakers. Another goal of the conference will be to continue to diversify the election science field.

Election scientists utilize social science theory to understand how elections operate and how citizens perceive them. Elections are administered at the state and local levels, which provides fertile ground to test theories such as rational choice, principal-agent, and representative bureaucracy. The conference will bring together election scholars, election practitioners, and local election-level experts to discuss and disseminate electoral science research. The scholars will use the interactions of the conference to generate new research questions, improve theories, and improve research designs. Broader Impacts of the conference include clear policy implications for election practitioners. The inclusion of practitioners in the conference increases the likelihood that science of elections will be incorporated into the administration of elections more generally. The project includes a clear plan for inclusion of women and under-representative groups. Additionally, undergraduate students are incorporated into conference activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Broader Impacts:

From our application: First, we predict the conference will incorporate scholars and students from traditionally underrepresented groups.

**We included many more women and those from underrepresented groups than the Election Science meeting had in the past. Of attendees, about 58 of them appeared to be women, and there were several more people of color in attendance than in the past. 

We also hope to increase the participation of local election officials by including a local electionofficial as the program co-chair. Incorporating practitioners into the conference also increases thelikelihood that science of elections will be incorporated into the administration of elections.

**We had broad participation from local election officials all over the country, but most particularly, North Carolina.

We estimate there were 27 local and state election officials in attendance, including North Carolina?s State Director of Elections and the State Director of Elections from Colorado. Significantly, three representatives from the U.S. House Administration Committee staff attended the conference. A staff member from the U.S. Election Assistance Commission attended as well as a representative of the contractor for the U.S. EAC?s Election Day Survey.

**We also worked for international diversity. Note: we had one team from Canada (see the article below by Holly Garnett and her team). We had one international graduate student, but they were unable to obtain a visa, and declined to zoom.

Intellectual Merit:

We wanted to see the publication of several works in election science. Thus, in collaboration with the editor-in-chief of Election Law Review (peer-reviewed), we decided to edit a special issue of the journal featuring papers presented at the conference. Dr. Canon and Dr. Kropf co-edited the issue. There was so much excitement around the issue that we will be publishing some of the articles in the December issue as well as the full June issue. My introduction, Kropf (2023), describes the papers published and to be published. See: Kropf, Martha. 2023. "Academic Scholarship and Election Official Perspectives at the Election Science, Reform and Administration Conference." Election Law Journal 22(2): 101-104.

 

Here is the table of contents for the June, 2023 issue of ELJ:

Volume 22                                   Number 2                               June 2023

 Original Articles

 Greenberger, Michael

"A Method to Detect Whether County-Wide Vote Centers are Located Optimally: The Case of North Carolina"

 

Garnett, Holly, Bordeleau, Jean-Nicolas; Stephenson, Laura; and Harell, Allison

"Contagious Elections: The Influence of COVID-19 on Comfort in Voting in Canadian Provincial Elections"

 

Herrnson, Paul; Stewart, Charles

"The Impact of COVID-19, Election Policies, and Partisanship on Voter Participation in the 2020 US Election"

 

Suttman-Lea, Mara and Merivaki, Lia

"The Impact of Voter Education on Voter Confidence-Evidence from the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election"

 

Ritter, Michael

"Assessing the Impact of the United States Postal System and Election Administration on Absentee and Mail Voting in U.S. Elections"

 

Gross, Joelle; Baltz, Samuel; and Stewart, Charles   

"What happens when the president calls you an 'enemy of the people'?"

 

The conference will stimulate research in a variety of ways. Like most conferences, we will bring together many scholars, leading and budding, to discuss and disseminate research. Unlike many conferences,however, we intentionally incorporate practitioners?election administrators. They attend the conference,

Here is a case where broader impacts and intellectual merit are similar. Note above where we mention how many election officials and other practitioners attended the conference. Academics had the opportunity to have many conversations with practitioners. And, toward the end of the conference, we had a brainstorming session for research ideas that election officials would like to see done

.
